title: AP - Every Stat matters, AD - DAMAGE!!!!
body: All opinions welcome, plus I'm just killing some time. In my own view, it seems like AP champs have to build an item for each stat. Obviously, ability power is the key but you need magic pen since maw and merc are so efficient, you need cooldown reduction since most cooldowns are 8-10 seconds, you need mana and probably mana regen, and if you don't build zhonyas........well we all know what happens if you don't build zhonyas. On the opposite side, for AD, you build items for damage, damage, and more damage. Critical strike? enhances damages. Attack speed? more damage per second. Lifesteal? return that damage so i can do more damage. Thats about it. So, while AP champs have to think about the best way to be teamfight efficient, these ability spamming auto-attacking AD champs are having their way.

Let's think about this...

AD champs have AD. AP champs have AP.

AD is typically capped at ~400max discounting Jhin and other gimmick passives i.e. Hecarim or Rammus.

AP is typically capped at ~800max discounting Veigar and others i.e. Cass or Thresh (yes thresh).
So AP champs can build more flat damage. Surely that isn't fair? Especially with Rabadons %increase. 
Incorrect. AD champs have IE, with a %increase of damage. The two stats come in completely different forms but perform their jobs well. 

AD casters use CDR.
AP casters use CDR. 

AD casters use mana.
AP casters use mana.
AD champs and AP champs BOTH use and benefit from Mana/Regen. Sorry but AD champs use mana just as often as AP champs, discounting AA-reliant champs.

AD has penetration. 
AP has penetration. 

AP has zhonyas.
AD has maw. 
We all know what happens if you don't buy zhonyas? You die.
We all know what happens if you don't buy maw? You die. 

Each class has nearly identical requirements. Sure they have their respective differences but if they didn't then it would completely defeat the purpose of having two classes of damage.

If AD offered the EXACT SAME BENEFITS as AP, why not just use AP?
Conversely, if AP offered the EXACT SAME
BENEFITS as AD, why not just use AD?

I don't believe either class is superior/inferior. 

I think people need to stop comparing the classes and realize, if you want to play a champ that benefits from maw... Play an AD champ. If you want zhonyas, play AP. But comparing the two and saying AP doesn't have the right number of options to compete with AD is fairly ignorant, no offense meant to you.

...except cdr is a stat roughly every champion (except for non-caster adcs both melee and ranged) cares about. Tanks, supports and AD assassins (such as nocturne or rengar) care greatly about CDR and will itemize heavily into those. It's not a "ap mage stat". It's an everyone stat.

and there's a thing called armour pen you conveniently left out of your post, despite bringing up mag pen as a stat that matters. And comparatively, there is substantially far greater armour items than there are MR items to deal with. At least try to make your post sound unbiased?

and then there's the lifesteal- What exactly do you mean by _return that damage so I can do more damage_? lifesteal doesn't uhhh.... do return damage? It's not thornmail. It's lifesteal: your attacks provide health based on damage dealt. It's a defensive tool similar to buying health regen on a champion (except it requires a victim to attack). It's a defensive sustain option just like how max mana/ max regen provides sustain for a caster (I hesitate to say mage, since again, tanks and supports do care about mana as well and also jayce who I would class as not a tank or a support). And the comparison between lifesteal and mana regen becomes even greater on certain casters, where mana/regen becomes literal sustain (healing) when certain abilities are used (such as swain or ahri or soraka).

Also, here's a link to the wiki
http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Mercury's_Treads
if you notice under cost analysis, mercury treads are 94% gold efficient (aka not cost efficient unless you factor in tenacity, who's value perpetually changes based on circumstance). And a lot of players have been forgoing these boots since you can already nab a good deal of tenacity off of the defensive tree (which is why any tank buys merc treads in the first place, you run a quick check when buying to see what cc the enemy has, then you decide if it's worth it).

and Maw of Malmortius actually sits at 99% cost efficiency until the passive is popped (which means that if you aren't taking magic damage, then the MR stat isn't being used and it rapidly drops below 100% efficiency). The thing about maw though, is it's not an item that anyone would rush first to maximize damage output. It's a reactive item for when you anticipate the enemy will be bursting you down with heavy magic damage. Most assassins would much rather be grabbing the almighty longsword, then building them into youmous or the new duskblade (or hydra). And most ADCS would rather build into IE/ER and then follow up with their attackspeed item.

And AD champions have to care about what items they buy as well:
after core AD items (AD champions do care about dishing out their damage of course), you need to build reactively to your opponent (otherwise you lose one teamfight and then deathtimers and then there goes your towers and there goes your nexus):
Heavy armor? go get some pen
Zed? go grab a QSS
Leblanc? go grab a hexdrinker
juggernaut fed? frozen mallet works wonders against garen
poke? you might be able to heal back some of that caitlyn headshot with lifesteal
basically, what I'm saying is that there are decisions to be made with AD. It's not just build pure damage. An ADC is expected to deal damage- which is why their core item build (usually big ad item+big attackspeed+crits item) is there. A similar case exists with mages- they don't blanket cover all stats in their builds. Usually they buy their core items (archangels+roa, athenes/morello/frostqueens (is this still a thing? is spooky ghosts mid still a thing?), liandries/rylais, ludens/abyssal scepter), then they too must decide if they want to invest in more ap with a deathcap or perhaps go for a void staff or hourglass or rylais or ludens or abysal scepter.

And finally, you're arguing that APs need to itemize towards every stat that affects their to contribute...
and then you say that ADs need to itemize both AD, attackspeed and critical strike chance...
which just means that ADs need to use every autoattack based stat possible as well to increase their DPS....
just like what you argued with casters using every spell-based stat (except for spellvamp, which is only purchased on champions who care about sustain)
perhaps you were trying to say that mages can contribute more than just damage, they contribute utility such as CC, buffs and support (in the form of healing/shielding).
So what? Is your argument that ADs are dealing too much damage? because you just said that ADs are just damage (like that's all they do, that's all they have). So... you want AP to provide more damage than AD on top of all of the utility? You want a playstyle entirely dedicated to dealing damage to not be the top tier damage dealer? That's terrible! That's what leads to imbalance. What's next, you want thresh to outheal soraka now? It's  that kind of logic that leads to Nautilus/malphite/Poppy 2.0 where we have a champion that provides immense cc, tankiness and as of recently 100-0 damage. A champion that generalises in everything without weakness of any type-but ore importantly, _one who outclasses everyone at their jobs._ Why pick a tank like sion who gives cc and tankiness when you could pick naut? And after your issue with AD and AP: why pick any AD champion if AP does more damage while providing utility?

And yet, aside from Jhin, I havent seen an adc with over 800 AD... 800 AP full build is pretty doable.
Full build rarely happens these days. So unless you build a {{item:3089}} right away, ADs are probably going to have an equivalent stat number

If you have a bloodthirster 75 AD (3700g) and an IE 65AD (3600g) and lvl 18 (we will say average 110 AD) and 15 AD from runes, total AD is 265.

AP user has Rabadon's 120 AP (3800g) and Rod of Ages, 120 AP (3000g) and 15 from Runes. Total AP 255*1.35= 344 AP. Not too similar if you ask me.

100% of that ad is going onto auto attacks (more if you get crits) while less than 100% is going on most abilities, not including ad scaling abilities and such.

Basically the point is building AD gives your abilities more damage and your basic attacks more damage, while building AP gives you a higher number but generally less of that number is being used as most abilities don't pack a 100% scaling

This. AP is not equivalent to AD. A case can be made for AoE making the argument grayer, but AD AoE is far from nonexistent. 

AD always has autos for a 100% ratio, at a frequent rate. AP rarely ever has a 100% coefficient, and when it does it's usually at a very low rate of use.
Perhaps you should explain why you think AP and AD are equivalent at 1:1

If you build 4 items with the highest base stat (no passives or actives), leave one slot for {{item:3089}}  and one slot for {{item:3031}} and one slot for boots, an AP build is {{item:3285}} (100) + {{item:3116}} (100) + {{item:3157}} (100) + whatever 80 item {{item:3165}} for example. So, that's 380. For AD, its {{item:3147}} , {{item:3072}} , {{item:3812}} , and {{item:3139}} . Thats 300 AD. An 80 point difference between the two isn't much and probably favors AD.

Even just going by what he said, comparing late game AP to AD, AD gets more value out of less stats because of auto attacks. There are in game constraints on it, and AoE becomes a point of contention, but AD ALWAYS has an option for a 1:1 ratio (autos), whereas AP is rarely ever 1:1, although it can be higher. So his argument simply doesn't work.

And in the case of ADCs even, AD gets heavily amplified so the raw numbers aren't going to line up just looking at the two scores.

Abilities typically have some or all of the following:

1) Better range

2) High base damages 

3) Soft CC

4) Hard CC

5) Area of Effect.

Its hard to compare it side by side since each ability is different. :/

I don't see a difference....

You build ap for DAMAGE
You build CDr to get DAMAGE out faster
You build mana to pump out DAMAGE for longer periods of time
You build magic pen for DAMAGE

When you are a damage carry, you tend to want damage.

Quick side note, I'm not saying do away with AD champs for most of you who came rushing to their defense. I'm saying the game doesn't have balance between the two damage types. There's a reason most lanes are becoming AD heavy. AP hardly exists top lane anymore except for your occasional ryze or vlad. Jungle, elise is still strong and gragas is making some noise, but mostly for his tankability. Mid, there's still a good amount of AP there so no compaints. Bot lane.......need I say more. So AD has main control of at least 3 out of 5 lanes (ADC, Jungle, Top). Supports are becoming more tank, at least in my games and Zed and Yasuo are growing in popularity. Minus bans.
What'd you expect from bot lane? Utility supports get nerfed for going mid and Riot consistently shits on sustain supports for being "uninteractive". All you're left with is tanky initiators/peelers.
